xxl.core.collections.containers
Class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.collections.containers.AbstractContainer
      xxl.core.collections.containers.ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
All Implemented Interfaces:
Container
Direct Known Subclasses:
BufferedContainer, ConverterContainer, CounterContainer, UnmodifiableContainer, VerificationContainer
public abstract class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
extends AbstractContainer

The class provides a constained decorator for a container. This class is similar to the decorator container, but it does not exactly follow the Decorator Design Pattern (for further details see Structural Patterns, Decorator in Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software by Erich Gamma, Richard Helm, Ralph Johnson, and John Vlissides). Whenever possible, the constrained decorator uses the default implementations of the container class. I.e., this class provides no usual decorator that simply redirects method call to an underlying container, but a kind of partial decorator that maps its methods to a set of central methods, which are decorated. Therefore, this class provides a way to profit from the default implementations of the container class and the advantages of decoration.

Note that this class provides only a workaround that allows the user to decorate only a single central method instead of a complete set of methods and therefore to save time.

Usage example (1). 

     // create a new decorated container that adds functionality to the insert method and leaves
     // the other methods untouched

     DecoratorContainer container = new DecoratorContainer(new MapContainer()) {
         public Object insert (Object object, boolean unfix) {

             // every desired functionality can be added to this method

             System.out.println("Before the insertion of the specified object!");
             Object object = super.insert(object, unfix);
             System.out.println("After the insertion of the specified object!");
             return object;
         }
     }

See Also:
Converter, Function, Iterator, NoSuchElementException

Field Detail

FACTORY_METHOD

public static final Function FACTORY_METHOD
A factory method to create a new DecoratorContainer. It may only be invoked with an array (parameter list) (for further details see Function) of containers. The array (parameter list) will be used to initialize the decorated container. This field is set to UnmodifiableContainer.FACTORY_METHOD.

See Also:
Function

container

protected Container container
A reference to the container to be decorated. This reference is used to perform method calls on the original container.

Method Detail

objectIdConverter

public FixedSizeConverter objectIdConverter()
Returns a converter for the ids generated by this container. A converter transforms an object to its byte representation and vice versa - also known as serialization in Java.
Since the identifier may have an arbitrary type (which has to be known in the container), the container has to provide such a method when the data is not stored in main memory.

Specified by:
objectIdConverter in interface Container
Specified by:
objectIdConverter in class AbstractContainer
Returns:
a converter for serializing the identifiers of the container.

getIdSize

public int getIdSize()
Returns the size of the ids generated by this container in bytes. This call is forwarded to the primary Container.

Specified by:
getIdSize in interface Container
Overrides:
getIdSize in class AbstractContainer
Returns:
the size in bytes of each id.

clear

public void clear()
Removes all elements from the Container. After a call of this method, size() will return 0.
Note, that the implementation of this method relies on the remove operation of the iterator returned by the method ids().

Specified by:
clear in interface Container
Overrides:
clear in class AbstractContainer

close

public void close()
Closes the Container and releases all sources. For external containers, this method closes the files immediately. MOREOVER, all iterators operating on the container can be in illegal states. Close can be called a second time without any impact. The default implementation of close is empty (which is OK for a MapContainer).
Note, that it would be desirable that the finalize-mechanism of Java would already offer the functionality of close. However, finalize does not release the sources immediately! Consequently, the corresponding file of a "closed" Container may be opened and some of the data is still not written back. This is a problem when for example the JVM stops running (because of a system error).

Specified by:
close in interface Container
Overrides:
close in class AbstractContainer

contains

public boolean contains(java.lang.Object id)
Returns true if the container contains an object for the identifier id.
Note, that when a user would like to store null objects in a container this method has to be reimplemented.

Specified by:

flush

public void flush()
Flushes all modified elements from the buffer into the container. After this call the buffer and the container are synchronized. The default implementation of flush is empty which is OK for an unbuffered container.

Specified by:
flush in interface Container
Overrides:
flush in class AbstractContainer

get

public java.lang.Object get(java.lang.Object id,
                            boolean unfix)
                     throws java.util.NoSuchElementException
Returns the object associated to the identifier id. An exception is thrown when the desired object is not found. If unfix, the object can be removed from the underlying buffer. Otherwise (!unfix), the object has to be kept in the buffer.

Specified by:

insert

public java.lang.Object insert(java.lang.Object object,
                               boolean unfix)
Inserts a new object into the container and returns the unique identifier that the container has been associated to the object. The identifier can be reused again when the object is deleted from the buffer. If unfixed, the object can be removed from the buffer. Otherwise, it has to be kept in the buffer until an unfix() is called.
After an insertion all the iterators operating on the container can be in an invalid state.
This method also allows an insertion of a null object. In the application would really like to have such objects in the container, some methods have to be modified.

Specified by:
insert in interface Container
Overrides:
insert in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
object - is the new object.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
the identifier of the object.

isUsed

public boolean isUsed(java.lang.Object id)
Checks whether the id has been returned previously by a call to insert or reserve and hasn't been removed so far.

Specified by:
isUsed in interface Container
Specified by:
isUsed in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
id - the id to be checked.
Returns:
true exactly if the id is still in use.

remove

public void remove(java.lang.Object id)
            throws java.util.NoSuchElementException
Removes the object with identifier id. An exception is thrown when an object with an identifier id is not in the container.
After a call of remove() all the iterators (and cursors) can be in an invalid state.

Specified by:
remove in interface Container
Specified by:
remove in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
id - an identifier of an object.
Throws:
java.util.NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier id is not in the container.

reserve

public java.lang.Object reserve(Function getObject)
Reserves an id for subsequent use. The container may or may not need an object to be able to reserve an id, depending on the implementation. If so, it will call the parameterless function provided by the parameter getObject.

Specified by:
reserve in interface Container
Specified by:
reserve in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
getObject - A parameterless function providing the object for that an id should be reserved.
Returns:

unfix

public void unfix(java.lang.Object id)
           throws java.util.NoSuchElementException
Unfixes the Object with identifier id. This method throws an exception when no element with an identifier id is in the container. After one call of unfix the buffer is allowed to remove the object (although the objects have been fixed more than once).
The default implementation only checks whether an object with identifier id is in the buffer.

Specified by:
unfix in interface Container
Overrides:
unfix in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
id - identifier of an object that should be unfixed in the buffer.
Throws:
java.util.NoSuchElementException - if no element with an identifier id is in the container.

update

public void update(java.lang.Object id,
                   java.lang.Object object,
                   boolean unfix)
            throws java.util.NoSuchElementException
Overwrites an existing (id,*)-element by (id, object). This method throws an exception if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container.

Specified by:
update in interface Container
Specified by:
update in class AbstractContainer
Parameters:
id - identifier of the element.
object - the new object that should be associated to id.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Throws:
java.util.NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container.
